awd_titl_txt: Increased Access to Authentic Research Through a Linked Sequence of Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experiences in Organic and Analytical Chemistry
awd_abstract_narration:
The ChemCUREs project will implement a Course-Based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) sequence in Chemistry that links a lower-division, organic chemistry course to an upper-division, analytical chemistry course. The goal of ChemCUREs is to transform the relationship between academic coursework and science research to enrich students' experience and enable greater research productivity for participating science faculty. The focus of student research will be the tardigrade, a microscopic extremophile, which produces sugar molecules to survive desiccation and freezing. ChemCUREs students will first create a variety of modified sugar molecules in the organic CURE, and then test the interaction properties of those molecules in the analytical CURE.  The study of these modified sugar molecules should lead to insights for the development of new cell preservatives. 

ChemCUREs will build on documented evidence of improvement in students' perceived participation and persistence in science coursework when enrolled in CUREs. In order to ascertain the causal mechanisms underlying the effectiveness and sustainability of CUREs, a comprehensive education research design will inform the collection of evidence from faculty and students in three university laboratory contexts: CUREs, conventional laboratory courses, and research internships.  Assessments of student learning will focus on experimental problem solving, laboratory skills, and writing in context for the three student cohorts. Evaluation of faculty will center on their development and implementation of ChemCURE series and their revision of the CUREs using empirical evidence.  Ultimately, the project will result in a transformed and sustainable system, and the process of course transformation will provide a unique opportunity to examine the effect of a CURE sequence that links a lower-division course to an upper-division course.

por.por_cntn:
The ChemCUREs project funded the implementation of a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) sequence that linked a lower-division, organic chemistry course to an upper-division, analytical chemistry course. The focus of student research was on blood preservation using trehalose derivatives to mimic the tardigrade, a microscopic extremophile, which produces sugar molecules to survive desiccation and freezing. Students created a library of modified sugar molecules in the Organic CURE and evaluated the behavior of those molecules within membranes in the Analytical CURE.  The CURE sequence was implemented with three student cohorts (N = 98) which were selected to match the demographics of all students in the corresponding lecture course. Key Lessons Learned are highlighted below:

  • Participant Selection: An application process imposes a potential barrier to non-STEM majors. In bringing research from a lower-level course to an upper-level course there is a need to have enough chemistry major participants in the lower-level CURE to continue into the upper-level CURE.
  • Course Structure/Schedule: The organic CURE was improved by splitting the 3-hour lab time over two consecutive days.
  • Team Science: Time was allotted each week for reflection and planning. Adding the weekly meeting to the CURE was found to have multiple benefits such as improved group communication, better use of laboratory time, and increased research productivity.

To ascertain the causal mechanisms underlying the effectiveness and sustainability of CUREs within the standard chemistry curriculum, we conducted research on students in CURE laboratories and Standard Instruction (SI) laboratories. Equivalency of the CURE and comparison groups was established based on demographic factors, reported gender and minority status, expected major, and grade in the pre-requisite course. A direct comparison of this nature revealed the benefits of the CURE sections and equality in assessment performance regardless of the instructional method.

The Classroom Undergraduate Research Experience (CURE) survey was adminstered to students in the organic II laboratory course.  CURE students reported significantly more very large gain responses on perceived learning gains regarding a lab or project where no one knows the outcome, working in small groups, becoming responsible for a part of the project, writing a research proposal, collecting data, and analyzing data. CURE students reported significantly more very large gain responses on course benefits items pertaining to skills in the interpretation of results, tolerance for obstacles faced in the research process, readiness for more demanding research, understanding how scientists work on real problems, understanding the scientific assertations require supporting evidence, ability to analyze data and other information, and learning laboratory techniques. Significantly more CURE students responded strongly agree on two overall evaluation items, this course was a good way of learning about the process of scientific research and this course had a positive effect on my interest in science. These reported gains support the research-based focus of the CURE. The Laboratory Course Assessment Survey (LCAS) was administered to student in the analytical chemistry course. Most notable in the LCAS analysis was the significantly higher gains for CURE student with a large effect for discovery and iteration. Both constructs are noted features of a CURE and would be expected to strongly differ from a SI laboratory experience.

Laboratory practical assessments were developed to document student progress, distinguish effective and ineffective aspects of the experiences, and illustrate how students interpret the research experiences they encounter. The organic laboratory practical exam and analytical exam provided empirical data that distinguished the CURE experience from the SI. The organic lab practical suggested that CURE participants developed greater proficiency with laboratory glassware. The analytical exam suggested that students in CURE were less proficient with calibration curve methods. The SI comparison students were regularly exposed to calibration curves in the analytical lab, whereas the CURE students were not. The exam scores demonstrated this distinction in the course content.

CUREs are typically limited to a single semester experience, whereas independent research experiences may evolve over multiple academic semesters. A multi-course CURE which allows student to continue the research project within their course of study provides the opportunity for more students to have the extended experience of this high-impact practice. Our results suggest, that replacing long-established instructional methods with course-based research experiences provides the benefits of research, without forfeiting development of knowledge, skills, and ability attendant with the laboratory course. This project was key to the development of additional CUREs within the chemistry curriculum as well as expansion to other science disciplines including, geology, biology, and engineering.
